translated: Abhidharma-jÃ±Äna-prasthÄna-Å›Ästra, fascicle 11
Composed by Venerable KÄtyÄyanÄ«putra
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on imperial commandğŸ”½Three practices correspond to three faculties,
And correspond to the ten paths of action.
Three karmas correspond to the ten paths, and the characteristics of karma are mutually inclusive in nine aspects.ğŸ”½Four statements on physical, verbal, and mental karmas,
What are the natures of the three hindrances?
What are the great sins with great consequences? Please explain this chapter in detail.
Do the three kinds of evil conduct and the three unwholesome roots include the latter?
Are the latter included in the former?
Answer:
One should make four statements.
There is evil conduct that is not an unwholesome root.
This refers to:
Evil conduct of body and speech, and unwholesome volition of wrong views.
There are unwholesome roots that are not evil conduct.
This refers to:
The unwholesome root of delusion.
There is evil conduct that is also an unwholesome root.
This refers to:
Greed, desire, and ill-will.
There is that which is neither evil conduct nor an unwholesome root.
This refers to:
Excluding the above characteristics.
Do the three good practices and the three roots of goodness include each other?
Are the latter included in the former?
Answer:
One should make four alternatives.
There is good practice that is not a root of goodness.
This refers to
the good practices of body and speech, and the good thoughts.
There are roots of goodness that are not good practices.
This refers to
the roots of goodness of non-delusion not included in right view.
There are good practices that are also roots of goodness.
This refers to
non-greed, non-hatred, and right view.
There are those that are neither good practices nor roots of goodness.
This refers to
excluding the above characteristics.
Do the three bad practices and the ten unwholesome courses of action include the three?
Do the ten include the three?
Answer:
The three include the ten, but the ten do not include the three.
What is not included?
This refers to
excluding the bad practices of body, speech, and mind included in the courses of action, the remaining bad practices of body, speech, and mind.
Do the three good practices and the ten wholesome courses of action include the three?
Do the ten include the three?
Answer:
Three subsume ten, but ten do not subsume three.
What are not subsumed?
They are:
Excluding the good bodily, verbal, and mental actions subsumed within the paths of action, the remaining good bodily, verbal, and mental actions.
Do the three actions and the ten paths of action subsume each other?
Do the ten subsume the three?
Answer:
One should make four alternatives.
There is action that is not a path of action.
They are:
Mental action, and bodily and verbal actions not subsumed within the paths of action.
There is a path of action that is not action.
They are:
The last three paths of action.
There is action that is also a path of action.
They are:
The first seven paths of action.
There is that which is neither action nor a path of action.
They are:
Excluding the above characteristics.
The three actions refer to:
Bodily, verbal, and mental actions.
The four actions refer to:
Black action with black ripening, white action with white ripening, black-and-white action with black-and-white ripening, and neither black nor white action with neither black nor white ripening.
Can the three exhaust all karmas, or do the four include the three?
Do the three include the four?
Answer:
The three include the four, but the four do not include the three.
What is not included?
Namely:
Excluding the wholesome volition of learners that can eliminate all karmas, the other uncontaminated karmas, the wholesome karmas bound to the formless realm, and all indeterminate karmas.
The three karmas are:
Bodily, verbal, and mental.
There are also three karmas, namely:
Karma to be experienced in the present life, karma to be experienced in the next life, and karma to be experienced in a subsequent lifetime.ğŸ”½Do the former include the latter?
Do the latter include the former?
Answer:
The former include the latter, but the latter do not include the former.
What is not included?
Namely:
Indeterminate karma, indeterminate karma, and uncontaminated karma.
The three karmas are:
Bodily, verbal, and mental.
There are also three karmas, namely:
Karma to be experienced as pleasant, karma to be experienced as painful, and karma to be experienced as neither painful nor pleasant.
Do the latter include the former?
Answer:
The former include the latter, but the latter do not include the former.
What is not included?
It refers to:
indeterminate karma and pure karma.
There are three kinds of karma, namely:
body, speech, and mind.
There are also three kinds of karma, namely:
past, future, and present karma.
There are also three kinds of karma, namely:
wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate karma.
There are also three kinds of karma, namely:
karma of the learner, karma of the post-learner, and karma of neither the learner nor the post-learner.
There are also three kinds of karma, namely:
karma to be eliminated by seeing the truths, karma to be eliminated by cultivation, and karma that is not to be eliminated.ğŸ”½Do the former include the latter?
Do the latter include the former?
Answer:
According to the matter.
They mutually include each other.
There are three kinds of karma, namely:
body, speech, and mind.
There are also three kinds of karma, namely:
karma bound to the desire realm, form realm, and formless realm.ğŸ”½Do the former include the latter?
Do the latter include the former?
Answer:
The former includes the latter, but the latter does not include the former.
What is not included?
It refers to:
Uncontaminated karma.
The four types of karma are as explained above.
The three types of karma refer to:
Karma to be experienced in the present life, etc.ğŸ”½Are the four included in the three?
Are the three included in the four?
The answer is:
One should make four alternatives.
There are four that are not three.
It refers to:
The wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate karma of the desire realm, and the wholesome and indeterminate karma of the form realm, which are the volition of learners who sever all karma.
There are three that are not four.
It refers to:
The wholesome and determinate karma of the formless realm.
There are four that are also three.
It refers to:
The wholesome and unwholesome determinate karma of the desire realm, and the wholesome and determinate karma of the form realm.
There are those that are neither four nor three.
It refers to:
Except for the volition of learners who sever all karma, the remaining uncontaminated karma, the wholesome and indeterminate karma of the formless realm, and the indeterminate karma.
The four types of karma are as explained above.
The three karmas are:
Karmas that accord with pleasant feelings, etc.ğŸ”½Do the four include the three?
Or do the three include the four?
Answer:
One should make four alternatives.
There are four that are not three.
They are:
The wholesome volition of learners that severs all karmas.
There are three that are not four.
They are:
The wholesome karmas bound to the formless realm.
There are four that are also three.
They are:
The wholesome and unwholesome karmas bound to the desire realm, and the wholesome karmas bound to the form realm.
There are those that are neither four nor three.
They are:
The remaining uncontaminated karmas, and the indeterminate karmas, excluding the wholesome volition of learners that severs all karmas.
The four karmas are as explained above.
The three karmas are:
Karmas of the past, etc., wholesome, etc., learner, etc., karmas to be eliminated by seeing, etc.ğŸ”½Do the four include the three?
Or do the three include the four?
Answer:
The three include the four, but the four do not include the three.
What are not included?
They are:

Excluding the wholesome volition that can sever all karmic bonds, the remaining uncontaminated karmic actions, the wholesome karmic actions bound to the formless realm, and the indeterminate karmic actions.
The four karmic actions are as explained above.
The three karmic actions refer to:
Those bound to the desire realm, etc.ğŸ”½Are the four subsumed by the three?
Are the three subsumed by the four?
Answer:
One should make four alternatives.
There are four that are not three.
They are:
The wholesome volition that can sever all karmic bonds.
There are three that are not four.
They are:
The wholesome karmic actions bound to the formless realm, and the indeterminate karmic actions.
There are four that are also three.
They are:
The wholesome and unwholesome karmic actions bound to the desire realm, and the wholesome karmic actions bound to the form realm.
There are those that are neither four nor three.
They are:
Excluding the wholesome volition that can sever all karmic bonds, the remaining uncontaminated karmic actions.
The three karmic actions refer to:
Those that are to be experienced in the present life, etc.
There are also three karmic actions, namely:
Those that are to be experienced with pleasant feeling, etc.ğŸ”½Are the former subsumed by the latter?
Are the latter subsumed by the former?
Answer:
The latter includes the former, but not vice versa.
What is not included?
It refers to
indeterminate karma.
The three types of karma refer to
karma to be experienced in the present life, etc.
There are also various other triads of karma.
They refer to
past, etc., wholesome, etc., training, etc., eliminated by seeing, etc.
Do the former include the latter, or do the latter include the former?
The answer is:
The latter include the former, but not vice versa.
What is not included?
It refers to
indeterminate karma, indeterminate karma, and pure karma.
The three types of karma refer to
karma to be experienced in the present life, etc.
There are also three types of karma, namely:
karma bound to the desire realm, etc.
Do the former include the latter, or do the latter include the former?
The answer is:
The latter include the former, but not vice versa.
What is not included?
It refers to
indeterminate karma and indeterminate karma.
The three types of karma refer to
karma to be experienced with pleasant feeling, etc. There are also various other triads of karma.
They refer to
past, etc., wholesome, etc., training, etc., to be abandoned by seeing, etc.ğŸ”½Are the former included in the latter?
Are the latter included in the former?
Answer:
The latter include the former, but the former do not include the latter.
What is not included?
It refers to:
indeterminate karma and pure karma.
The three kinds of karma refer to:
karma that results in pleasant feeling, etc.
There are also three kinds of karma, namely:
karma bound to the desire realm, etc.ğŸ”½Are the former included in the latter?
Are the latter included in the former?
Answer:
The latter include the former, but the former do not include the latter.
What is not included?
It refers to:
indeterminate karma.
The three kinds of karma refer to:
past, etc.
There are also various kinds of three karma, namely:
wholesome, etc., training, etc., to be abandoned by seeing, etc.ğŸ”½Are the former included in the latter?
Are the latter included in the former?
Answer:
According to the matter, they mutually include each other.
The three kinds of karma refer to:
past, etc.
There are also three kinds of karma, namely:
Those associated with the desire realm, etc.ğŸ”½Do the former include the latter?
Or do the latter include the former?
Answer:
The former include the latter, but the latter do not include the former.
What is not included?
Namely,
Uncontaminated karma.
The three types of karma are:
There are also three types of karma, namely:
Those associated with the desire realm, etc. Do the former include the latter?
Or do the latter include the former?
Answer:
The former include the latter, but the latter do not include the former.
What is not included?
Namely,
Uncontaminated karma.
The three types of karma are:
There are also various other types of karma, namely:
Those of the learner, etc., and those eliminated by seeing, etc.ğŸ”½Do the former include the latter?
Or do the latter include the former?
Answer:
According to the matter, they mutually include each other.
The three types of karma are:
There are also various other types of karma, namely:
Those of the learner, etc., and those eliminated by seeing, etc.ğŸ”½Do the former include the latter?
Or do the latter include the former?
Answer:
The latter includes the former, but not vice versa.
What is not included?
It refers to
undefiled karma.
There are three kinds of karma, namely:
karma of the learners, etc.
There are also three kinds of karma, namely:
karma to be eliminated by the path of insight, etc.
Do the former include the latter, or do the latter include the former?
The answer is:
According to the matter, they mutually include each other.
Is there any karma that produces bodily feeling but not mental feeling?
The answer is:
There is.
It refers to
unwholesome karma.
Is there any karma that produces mental feeling but not bodily feeling?
The answer is:
There is.
It refers to
wholesome karma without initial thought.
Is there any karma that produces bodily and mental feeling?
The answer is:
There is.
It refers to
wholesome karma with initial thought.
Is there any karma that does not produce bodily and mental feeling but produces retribution?
The answer is:
There is.
It refers to
karma that produces form and factors not directly associated with mind as retribution.
As it is said, there are three kinds of obstacles, namely:
Afflictive hindrances, karmic hindrances, and resultant hindrances.
What are the afflictive hindrances?
They are:

There are those whose nature is fully endowed with the blazing afflictions of greed, hatred, and delusion. Because of this, it is difficult for them to give rise to disgust, difficult to instruct them, difficult to enlighten them, difficult to get them to escape, and difficult to get them to be liberated.
What are the karmic hindrances?
They are:
The five heinous acts.
What are the resultant hindrances?
They are:
The realms of sentient beings - the hells, animals, hungry ghosts, the northern continent of Kuru, and the heaven of non-perceptual beings.
Among the three evil actions, which has the greatest offense?
It is:
The false speech of breaking the harmony of the Sangha. This karma can take the result of a lifespan of one eon in the AvÄ«ci Hell.
Among the three good actions, which has the greatest result?
It is:
The volition in the meditative absorption of the peak of existence. This karma can take the result of an eighty-thousand-eons lifespan in the heaven of neither perception nor non-perception.
Three kinds of right and wrong, one and different, three kinds of evil conduct, crookedness, etc.
The characteristics of sublimity, purity, silence, and inclusion, the six phrases of unreasonableness, etc.
The three periods of time in which karma obtains its results, the eight phrases of the results of retribution,
The five kinds of karma are not sequential. I wish to fully explain this chapter.
Are all wrong speech also wrong livelihood?
If it is wrong livelihood, is it also wrong speech?
Answer:
One should make four phrases.
There is wrong speech that is not wrong livelihood.
This refers to
all wrong speech other than the four kinds of verbal evil conduct arising from greed.
There is wrong livelihood that is not wrong speech.
This refers to
the three kinds of bodily evil conduct arising from greed. There is wrong speech and also wrong livelihood.
This refers to
the four kinds of verbal evil conduct arising from greed.
There is that which is neither wrong speech nor wrong livelihood.
This refers to
all bodily evil conduct other than the three kinds of bodily evil conduct arising from greed.
Are all wrong actions also wrong livelihood?
If it is wrong livelihood, are they also wrong actions?
Answer:
There should be four alternatives.
There is wrong action but not wrong livelihood.
This refers to
all bodily misconduct other than the three bodily misdeeds arising from greed.
There is wrong livelihood but not wrong action.
This refers to
the four verbal misdeeds arising from greed.
There is both wrong action and wrong livelihood.
This refers to
the three bodily misdeeds arising from greed.
There is neither wrong action nor wrong livelihood.
This refers to
all verbal misconduct other than the four verbal misdeeds arising from greed.
For all right speech, is it also right livelihood?
If it is right livelihood, is it also right speech?
The answer is:
There should be four alternatives.
There is right speech but not right livelihood.
This refers to
all verbal good conduct other than the four verbal good conducts arising from non-greed.
There is right livelihood but not right speech.
This refers to
the three bodily good conducts arising from non-greed.
There is both right speech and right livelihood.
This refers to
the four verbal good conducts arising from non-greed.
There is that which is neither right speech nor right livelihood.
This refers to:
The three kinds of good bodily conduct that are not produced by non-greed, and the remaining bodily good conduct.
For all right actions, is there right livelihood?
If there is right livelihood, is there right action?
The answer is:
One should make four statements.
There is right action that is not right livelihood.
This refers to:
The three kinds of good bodily conduct that are not produced by non-greed, and the remaining bodily good conduct.
There is right livelihood that is not right action.
This refers to:
The four kinds of good verbal conduct that are produced by non-greed.
There is right action that is also right livelihood.
This refers to:
The three kinds of good bodily conduct that are produced by non-greed.
There is that which is neither right action nor right livelihood.
This refers to:
The four kinds of good verbal conduct that are not produced by non-greed, and the remaining verbal good conduct.
The three kinds of evil conduct, the three kinds of crooked, foul, and turbid, refer to:
Bodily crookedness, bodily impurity, bodily turbidity, verbal crookedness, verbal impurity, verbal turbidity, mental crookedness, mental impurity, mental turbidity - three.
What is meant by crookedness?
It refers to:
The bodily, verbal, and mental actions arising from flattery.
What is meant by impurity?
It refers to:
The bodily, verbal, and mental actions arising from hatred.
What is meant by turbidity?
It refers to:
The bodily, verbal, and mental actions arising from greed.ğŸ”½Are crookedness, impurity, and turbidity included in the three kinds of misconduct?
Are the three kinds of misconduct included in crookedness, impurity, and turbidity?
Answer:
One should make four alternatives.
There is misconduct that is not crookedness, impurity, or turbidity.
It refers to:
All bodily, verbal, and mental misconduct except for the bodily, verbal, and mental misconduct arising from flattery, hatred, and greed in the desire realm.
There is crookedness, impurity, and turbidity that are not misconduct.
It refers to:
The bodily, verbal, and mental actions produced by flattery and greed in the first meditation, as well as the mental actions produced by greed in the other form and formless realms.
There are bad conduct that are also crooked, foul, and turbid.
Namely:
The bodily, verbal, and mental bad conduct produced by flattery, hatred, and greed in the desire realm.
There are those that are neither bad conduct nor crooked, foul, and turbid.
Namely:
Excluding the above characteristics.
The three good conducts and the three purities, namely:
The purity of body, speech, and mind.ğŸ”½Are the good conducts included in the purities?
Or are the purities included in the good conducts?
Answer:
According to the matter.
They mutually include each other.
The three good conducts and the three silences.
Namely:
The silence of body, speech, and mind.ğŸ”½Are the good conducts included in the silences?
Or are the silences included in the good conducts?
Answer:
One should make four statements.
There are good conducts that are not silences.
Namely:
Excluding the bodily and verbal good conduct of the non-learner, the remaining bodily and verbal good conduct,
and all mental good conduct.
There is silence that is not good conduct.
It refers to
the mind of the non-learner.
There is good conduct that is also silence.
It refers to
the bodily and verbal good conduct of the non-learner.
There is that which is neither good conduct nor silence.
It refers to
excluding the above characteristics.ğŸ”½Are the three purities and the three silences subsumed by purity,
or are the three silences subsumed by purity?
Answer:
One should make four alternatives.
There is purity that is not silence.
It refers to
excluding the bodily and verbal purity of the non-learner, the remaining bodily and verbal purity, and all mental purity.
There is silence that is not purity.
It refers to
the mind of the non-learner.
There is purity that is also silence.
It refers to
the bodily and verbal purity of the non-learner.
There is that which is neither purity nor silence.
It refers to
excluding the above characteristics.
Are all bodily misdeeds necessarily bodily actions that are instigated by improper mental states?
If they are bodily actions instigated by improper mental states, are they all bodily misdeeds?
Answer:
All bodily misdeeds are necessarily bodily actions that are instigated by improper mental states.
There are bodily actions instigated by improper mental states that are not bodily misdeeds.
Namely,

bodily actions that are ethically neutral due to being obscured, and ethically neutral bodily actions that are instigated by improper mental states.ğŸ”½Are all verbal misdeeds necessarily verbal actions that are instigated by improper mental states?
If they are verbal actions instigated by improper mental states, are they all verbal misdeeds?
Answer:
All verbal misdeeds are necessarily verbal actions that are instigated by improper mental states.
There are verbal actions instigated by improper mental states that are not verbal misdeeds.
Namely,
verbal actions that are ethically neutral due to being obscured, and ethically neutral verbal actions that are instigated by improper mental states.
Are all mental misdeeds necessarily mental actions that are instigated by improper mental states?
If it is not a mental action drawn by improper means, does it all belong to mental bad conduct?
Answer:
One should make four alternatives.
There is mental bad conduct that is not a mental action drawn by improper means.
This refers to
greed, ill-will, and wrong views.
There is a mental action drawn by improper means that is not mental bad conduct.
This refers to
the obscured indeterminate mental action, and the unobscured indeterminate mental action drawn by improper means.
There is mental bad conduct that is also a mental action drawn by improper means.
This refers to
the unwholesome mental action.
There is that which is neither mental bad conduct nor a mental action drawn by improper means.
This refers to
excluding the above characteristics.ğŸ”½Do all bodily good actions belong to bodily actions drawn by proper means?
If it is a bodily action drawn by proper means, does it all belong to bodily good actions?
Answer:ğŸ”½All bodily good actions belong to bodily actions drawn by proper means.
There is a bodily action drawn by proper means that does not belong to bodily good actions.
It is said:
Unwholesome and indeterminate bodily actions that are induced by proper reasoning.ğŸ”½Do all verbal good actions consist of verbal actions that are induced by proper reasoning?
If it is verbal action that is induced by proper reasoning, does it all consist of verbal good actions?
The answer is:
All verbal good actions consist of verbal actions that are induced by proper reasoning.
There is verbal action that is induced by proper reasoning, but does not consist of verbal good actions.
It is said:
Unwholesome and indeterminate verbal actions that are induced by proper reasoning.ğŸ”½Do all mental good actions consist of mental actions that are induced by proper reasoning?
If it is mental action that is induced by proper reasoning, does it all consist of mental good actions?
The answer is:
Four sentences should be made.
There is mental good action that is not mental action induced by proper reasoning.
It is said:
Non-greed, non-hatred, and right view.
There is mental action induced by proper reasoning that is not mental good action.
It is said:
Unwholesome and indeterminate mental actions that are induced by proper reasoning.
There is right mental action that is also mental action in accordance with reason.
This refers to
wholesome mental action.
There is mental action that is neither right mental action nor mental action in accordance with reason.
This refers to
excluding the above characteristics.
For dharmas obtained through karma, should those dharmas be said to be wholesome,
unwholesome,
or indeterminate?
Answer:
Dharmas obtained through karma in dependence on the result of retribution are those dharmas that are indeterminate.
It is definitely said:
Are dharmas obtained through karma in dependence on the result of retribution those dharmas that are indeterminate?
Answer:
It is so.
What do you wish to say?
The TathÄgata speaks with a wholesome mind, with a wonderful voice, a beautiful voice, a harmonious voice, a pleasing voice - is this speech wholesome?
Answer:
It is so.
If it is said:
Dharmas obtained through karma in dependence on the result of retribution are those dharmas that are indeterminate,
then it should not be said:
The TathÄgata speaks with a good mind, with a wonderful voice, a beautiful voice, a harmonious voice, a pleasing voice, this speech is good.
One who speaks thus, it is not reasonable.
If one speaks thus:
The TathÄgata speaks with a good mind, with a wonderful voice, a beautiful voice, a harmonious voice, a pleasing voice, this speech is good.
Then one should not say:
Based on the ripening fruit, dharmas are obtained by karma, those dharmas are indeterminate.
Speaking thus, it is not reasonable.
One should speak thus:
In the past, in other lives, the Bodhisattva created and increased karma that would ripen, and produced a great and extensive body;
By this cause and condition, the TathÄgata's throat was gradually born from the great elements;
From this, he was able to produce the wonderful voice of speech;
But the voice is not ripening.
Are all karmas in the past, their fruits in the past?
Answer:
Their fruits may be past, future, or present.
For all actions that are future, are their fruits future?
Answer:
It is so.
For all actions that are present, are their fruits present?
Answer:
Their fruits may be present or future.
Can there be bodily action that produces a different ripening than verbal and mental action?
Answer:
There can be.
For example, when one does not guard the body but guards speech,
at that time one has a wholesome or indeterminate mind.
Moreover,
when one guards the body but does not guard speech,
at that time one has an unwholesome or indeterminate mind.
Can there be verbal action that produces a different ripening than bodily and mental action?
Answer:
There can be.
For example, when one guards the body but does not guard speech,
at that time one has a wholesome or indeterminate mind.
The opposite cases are also explained in the same way.
Can there be a case where a mental action produces a ripening, but bodily and verbal actions do not?
Answer:
There can be.
For example, when there is bodily restraint and verbal restraint,
at that time there is an unwholesome mind.
When there is bodily unrestraint and verbal unrestraint,
at that time there is a wholesome mind.
Can there be a case where the ripening of bodily action and verbal action is like that of mental action?
Answer:
There can be.
When there is bodily unrestraint and verbal unrestraint,
at that time there is a wholesome mind or a neutral mind.
When there is bodily restraint and verbal restraint,
at that time there is an unwholesome mind or a neutral mind.
Can there be a case where the ripening of bodily action and mental action is like that of verbal action?
Answer:
There can be.ğŸ”½When there is bodily unrestraint and verbal restraint, at that time there is an unwholesome mind.
When there is bodily restraint and verbal unrestraint, at that time there is a wholesome mind.
Can there be bodily action and verbal and mental actions that produce results, but not bodily action?
Answer:
There can be.
For example, when one guards the body but not speech, at that time there is an unwholesome mind.
When one does not guard the body but guards speech, at that time there is a wholesome mind.
Can there be bodily and verbal actions that produce results, and also mental actions that do so?
Answer:
There can be.
For example, when one does not guard the body and does not guard speech, at that time there is an unwholesome mind.
When one guards the body and guards speech, at that time there is a wholesome mind.
Can there be non-bodily, non-verbal, and non-mental actions that produce results, but not bodily, verbal, or mental actions?
Answer:
There can be.
It refers to
the formations not associated with the mind that produce the results of form, mental factors associated with the mind, and formations not associated with the mind.
Can there be the three kinds of actions that produce results in the present life, etc., that produce results before or after?
Answer:
There can be.
Namely:
Karma to be experienced in the present life - form.ğŸ”½Karma to be experienced in the next life - mind and mental factors.
Karma to be experienced in a subsequent life - factors not directly associated with mind.
Moreover,
Karma to be experienced in the present life - factors not directly associated with mind.
Karma to be experienced in the next life - form.
Karma to be experienced in a subsequent life - mind and mental factors.
Moreover,
Karma to be experienced in the present life - mind and mental factors.
Karma to be experienced in the next life - factors not directly associated with mind.
Karma to be experienced in a subsequent life - form.
Are there three kinds of karma that lead to pleasant feelings, etc., whose results are experienced neither before nor after?
Answer:
There are.
Namely:
Karma that leads to pleasant feelings - form.
Karma that leads to painful feelings - mind and mental factors.
Karma that leads to neither painful nor pleasant feelings - factors not directly associated with mind.ğŸ”½Moreover,
Moreover,ğŸ”½ğŸ”½
Actions that accord with pleasant feeling are formations not associated with the mind.
Actions that accord with painful feeling are form.
Actions that accord with neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling are mind and mental factors.
Moreover,
actions that accord with pleasant feeling are mind and mental factors.
Actions that accord with painful feeling are formations not associated with the mind.
Actions that accord with neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling are form.
Are there any actions in the three realms that do not experience the results of karma before or after?
Answer:
There are.
Namely,
actions bound to the desire realm are form.
Actions bound to the form realm are mind and mental factors.
Actions bound to the formless realm are formations not associated with the mind.
Moreover,
actions bound to the desire realm are formations not associated with the mind.
Actions bound to the form realm are form.
Actions bound to the formless realm are mind and mental factors.
Moreover,
actions bound to the desire realm are mind and mental factors.
The karma of the form realm - factors not directly associated with the mind.
The karma bound to the formless realm - form.
Can there be wholesome and unwholesome karma that does not experience the ripening of its fruits either before or after?
Answer:
There can be.
Namely,
wholesome karma - form.
Unwholesome karma - mind, mental factors, and factors not directly associated with the mind.
Moreover,
wholesome karma - mind, mental factors, and factors not directly associated with the mind.
Unwholesome karma - form.
Can there be karma to be eliminated by seeing and cultivation that does not experience the ripening of its fruits either before or after?
Answer:
There can be.
Namely,
karma to be eliminated by seeing - form.
Karma to be eliminated by cultivation - mind, mental factors, and factors not directly associated with the mind.
Moreover,
karma to be eliminated by seeing - mind, mental factors, and factors not directly associated with the mind.
Karma to be eliminated by cultivation - form.
Taking life is of four kinds, with two maturations and two protections.
Body and action are accomplished, with defiled fruits and retributions.
Unwholesome, inverted, etc., bound and unbound are accomplished.
At the time of death, the place of rebirth, I wish to fully explain this chapter.
Can there be killing of living beings where the killing has already occurred but not yet ceased?
Answer:
There can be.
For example, if one has already taken the life of another but the preparatory action has not yet ceased.
Can there be killing of living beings where the killing has not yet occurred but has already ceased?
Answer:
There can be.
For example, if one has not yet taken the life of another but the preparatory action has already ceased.
Can there be killing of living beings where the killing has already occurred and has already ceased?
Answer:
There can be.
For example, if one has already taken the life of another and the preparatory action has already ceased.
Can there be killing of living beings where the killing has not yet occurred and has not yet ceased?
Answer:
There can be.
For example, if one has not yet taken the life of another but the preparatory action has not yet ceased.
Can there be killing of living beings where the killing has not yet occurred and has not yet ceased, and this karma is definitely to be experienced in hell?
Answer:
There can be.
For example, when one is about to commit an immediate [evil] action, one's life ends.

Is there any unwholesome karma that has suffering as its ripening, but whose ripening has not yet matured, and yet one does not first experience the ripening of its result, and gives rise to a defiled mind?
Answer:
There is.
For example, after one has created and increased the immediate karma, this karma first experiences the ripening of its result, which is the intermediate existence in hell.
Is there anyone who, after intentionally killing a living being, does not accept the precept of non-killing, yet still obtains the protection of all sentient beings?
Answer:
There is.
For example, when one is about to carry out the act of killing, and the other person is certain to die, but in the meantime one realizes the nature of the Dharma.
If one obtains the protection of all sentient beings,
does one accept the precept of non-killing from all sentient beings?
Answer:
One should make four statements.
There are those who obtain the protection of all sentient beings, but do not accept the precept of non-killing.
For example,
those who do not accept the precepts but realize the nature of the Dharma.
There is [the case of] one who has the avoidance of all sentient beings, but not the attainment of protection.
For example,
one who has taken the precepts but violates the avoidance [of evil].
There is [the case of] one who has the attainment of protection of all sentient beings, and also the avoidance.
For example,
one who has taken the precepts and does not violate the avoidance.
There is [the case of] one who does not have the attainment of protection of all sentient beings, nor the avoidance.
This refers to
excluding the above characteristics.
If one has a body, does one have bodily karma?
The answer is:
One should make four statements.
There is [the case of] one who has a body but not bodily karma.
This refers to

one who is in an egg, or an ordinary person dwelling in the womb, or one born in the desire realm, dwelling in neither discipline nor non-discipline, without bodily expression, or having had it but lost it.
There is [the case of] one who has bodily karma but not a body.
This refers to
a noble one born in the formless realm.
There is [the case of] one who has both a body and bodily karma.
This refers to

If the noble ones abide in the womb, or if born in the desire realm, abiding in precepts, unwholesome conduct, or neither, and currently have bodily expression, or previously had it without losing it.
If born in the form realm.
There are those who do not possess a body and also do not possess bodily action.
This refers to:
Ordinary beings born in the formless realm.
If one possesses a body, does one also possess verbal action?
The answer is:
One should make four statements.
There are those who possess a body but not verbal action.
This refers to:
Those in an egg, or ordinary beings abiding in the womb, or born in the desire realm, abiding in neither discipline nor non-discipline;
who do not have any verbal expression at all, or even if they had it, have lost it.
There are those who possess verbal action but not a body.
This refers to:
Noble ones born in the formless realm.
There are those who possess both a body and verbal action.
All noble ones dwelling in the womb, if born in the desire realm, abide in precepts, if abiding in unwholesome conduct, or if abiding in neither precepts nor unwholesome conduct;
currently possessing verbal expression, or previously having it without losing it.
If born in the form realm.
There are those who do not possess bodily action and also do not possess verbal action.
This refers to:
All ordinary beings born in the formless realm.
If one possesses a body, does one also possess mental action?
Answer:
Those who possess a body definitely possess mental action.
There are those who possess mental action but not a body, namely:
Those born in the formless realm.
If one possesses a body, does one also possess bodily action and verbal action?
Answer:
There are those who possess a body but not bodily action or verbal action.
This refers to:
Those dwelling in an egg.
If ordinary beings dwell in the womb.
If born in the desire realm, abiding in neither precepts nor unwholesome conduct, without bodily or verbal expression, even if having it, it is lost.
There are those who have a body and bodily actions but not verbal actions.
This refers to
those born in the desire realm who abide in neither discipline nor non-discipline, who currently have bodily expression or who previously had it without losing it.
They do not have verbal expression, or even if they had it, they have lost it.
There are those who have a body and verbal actions but not bodily actions.
This refers to
those born in the desire realm who abide in neither discipline nor non-discipline, who currently have verbal expression or who previously had it without losing it.
They do not have bodily expression, or even if they had it, they have lost it.
There are those who have a body and both bodily and verbal actions.
This refers to
noble ones abiding in the womb;
if born in the desire realm, abiding in discipline;
if abiding in non-discipline or neither discipline nor non-discipline, and currently having bodily and verbal expression, or previously having it without losing it;
if born in the form realm.
If one has bodily actions and verbal actions, do they have a body?
The answer is:
They may or may not have a body.
How is it accomplished?
It is as explained above.
How is it not accomplished?
It is as follows:
The noble ones who are born in the formless realm.
If one accomplishes the body, does one accomplish bodily action and mental action?
The answer is:
There are those who accomplish the body and mental action but not bodily action.
It is as follows:ğŸ”½Those who are in an egg.
Those ordinary beings who are in the womb.
Those born in the desire realm.
Abiding in neither discipline nor non-discipline.
Without bodily expression.
Even if there is, it is lost.
There are those who accomplish the body, bodily action, and mental action.
It is as follows:
The noble ones who are in the womb;
Those born in the desire realm who abide in discipline, non-discipline, and neither discipline nor non-discipline, who currently have bodily expression, or who previously had it without losing it;
Those born in the form realm.
If one accomplishes bodily action and mental action, does one accomplish the body?
The answer is:
Either one accomplishes it or one does not accomplish it.
How is it accomplished?
It is as explained above.
How is it not accomplished?
It is as follows:
The noble ones who are born in the formless realm.
If one accomplishes the body, does one also accomplish verbal and mental actions?
The answer is:
There are those who accomplish the body and mental actions but not verbal actions.
There are those who accomplish the body, verbal actions, and mental actions.
These are all as explained above in the section on the body, bodily actions, and mental actions.
The difference is:
This explains verbal expression.
If one accomplishes verbal actions and mental actions, does one also accomplish the body?
The answer is:
Either one accomplishes it or one does not accomplish it;
It is also as explained in that [passage].
If one accomplishes the body, does one also accomplish bodily actions, verbal actions, and mental actions?
The answer is:ğŸ”½There are those who accomplish the body and mental actions but not bodily actions or verbal actions.
There are those who accomplish the body, bodily actions, and mental actions but not verbal actions.
There are those who have bodily and verbal actions and mental actions, but not bodily actions.
There are those who have bodies and bodily actions, verbal actions, and mental actions.
These are all as explained above in the section on bodies corresponding to bodily actions and verbal actions.
If one has bodily actions, verbal actions, and mental actions, do they have a body?
Answer:
Either they have it or they do not have it;
it is also as explained there.
If one has bodily actions, do they have verbal actions?
Answer:
One should make four statements.
There are those who have bodily actions but not verbal actions.
This refers to:
Being born in the desire realm.
Abiding in neither discipline nor non-discipline.
Currently having bodily expression.
Or having it previously without losing it.
Not having verbal expression.
Even if having it, losing it.
There are those who have verbal actions but not bodily actions.
This refers to:
Being born in the desire realm.
Abiding in neither discipline nor non-discipline.
Currently having verbal expression.
Or, if one previously had [good or bad conduct], one has not lost it.
There is no bodily expression.
Even if one has it, one has lost it.
There are those who accomplish bodily action and verbal action.
That is to say:
Noble ones dwelling in the womb.
If born in the desire realm,ğŸ”½Dwelling in precepts, unprecepts,
And dwelling in neither precepts nor unprecepts.
Currently having bodily and verbal expression.
Or, if one previously had [good or bad conduct], one has not lost it.
If born in the form realm.
If noble ones are born in the formless realm.
There are those who do not accomplish bodily action and verbal action.
That is to say:
Dwelling in an egg.
If ordinary beings dwell in the womb.
If born in the desire realm,
Dwelling in neither precepts nor unprecepts.
Without bodily and verbal expression.
Even if one has it, one has lost it.
If ordinary beings are born in the formless realm.
If one accomplishes bodily action, does one accomplish mental action?
Answer:
If one accomplishes bodily action, one accomplishes mental action.
There are those who accomplish mental action but not bodily action.
That is to say:
Abiding in the egg.
If an ordinary person abides in the womb.
If born in the desire realm.
Abiding in neither discipline nor non-discipline.
Without bodily expression, even if there was, it is lost.
If an ordinary person is born in the formless realm.
If one accomplishes bodily action, does one also accomplish verbal action and mental action?
Answer:
There are those who accomplish bodily action and mental action, but not verbal action.
This refers to:
Being born in the desire realm.
Abiding in neither discipline nor non-discipline.
Currently having bodily expression.
Or having it previously without losing it.
Without verbal expression.
Even if there was, it is lost.
There are those who accomplish bodily action, verbal action, and mental action.
This refers to:
Noble ones abiding in the womb.
If born in the desire realm.
Abiding in discipline, non-discipline, and also abiding in neither discipline nor non-discipline.
Currently having bodily and verbal expression.
Or having it previously without losing it.ğŸ”½If born in the form realm.
If noble ones are born in the formless realm.
If one possesses verbal and mental actions, does one possess bodily actions?
Answer:
Either one possesses or does not possess.
How does one possess?
It is said:
As explained above.
How does one not possess?
It is said:
Being born in the desire realm.
Abiding in neither discipline nor non-discipline.
Currently possessing verbal expression.
Or previously having it without losing it.
Lacking bodily expression.
Even if having it, losing it.
If one possesses verbal actions, does one possess mental actions?
Answer:
Those who possess verbal actions also possess mental actions.
There are those who possess mental actions but not verbal actions.
This is as explained above in the case of bodily actions versus mental actions.
The difference is:
This refers to verbal expression.
If an action is not yet free from defilements, is its retribution not yet free from defilements?
Answer:
All actions that are not yet free from defilements, their retributions are not yet free from defilements.
There may be some with retribution that is not yet free from defilements, while that karma is already free from defilements.
This refers to:
The karma to be eliminated by seeing of a stream-enterer is already free from defilements, but its retribution is not yet free from defilements.
If karma is already free from defilements, is its retribution also already free from defilements?
Answer:
All retribution that is already free from defilements, that karma is already free from defilements.
There may be some karma that is already free from defilements, while its retribution is not yet free from defilements.
This refers to:
The karma to be eliminated by seeing of a stream-enterer is already free from defilements, but its retribution is not yet free from defilements.
If karma has a result, does that karma all have retribution?
Answer:
All karma that has retribution, that karma all has a result.
There may be some karma that has a result, while that karma does not have retribution.
This refers to:
Indeterminate karma and pure karma.
If karma has no result, does that karma all have no retribution?
Answer:
There is no karma that has no result.
There may be some karma that has no retribution.
This refers to:
Indeterminate karma and pure karma.
If an action is unwholesome, is that action all inverted?
Answer:
One should make four alternatives.
There is an action that is unwholesome, but that action is not inverted.
This refers to:
As when someone gives rise to this view and establishes this thesis:
There is karma and there is the ripening of karma and its results, yet they engage in evil bodily, verbal, and mental actions.
Moreover,
as when someone:
Regarding what exists, has the notion that it does not exist.
Regarding what is heard, cognized, and known, has the notion that it is not heard, cognized, and known. They conceal this notion, this forbearance, this desire, and say:
I see, I hear, cognize, and know.

Or regarding what is not seen, has the notion that it is seen, regarding what is not heard, cognized, and known, has the notion that it is heard, cognized, and known. They conceal this notion, this forbearance, this desire, and say:
I do not see, do not hear, cognize, and know.
There are inverted actions that are not unwholesome.
Namely:
Suppose there is someone who gives rise to this view and establishes this thesis:
There is no action, no result of action and ripening.
Yet they practice good conduct of body, speech, and mind.
Moreover,
suppose there is someone:

Regarding what is seen, they have the notion of not seeing, regarding what is heard, cognized, and known, they have the notion of not hearing, cognizing, and knowing. They do not conceal this notion, this forbearance, this desire, and say:
I do not see, I do not hear, cognize, or know.

Or regarding what is not seen, they have the notion of seeing, regarding what is not heard, cognized, or known, they have the notion of hearing, cognizing, and knowing. They do not conceal this notion, this forbearance, this desire, and say:
I see, I hear, cognize, and know.
There are actions that are unwholesome and also inverted.
Namely:
Suppose there is someone who gives rise to this view and establishes this thesis:
There is no karma, no ripening of karma, and they still engage in evil bodily, verbal, and mental actions.
Moreover,
it is like a person

who, regarding what is seen, has the conception of having seen, and regarding what is heard, cognized, and known, has the conception of having heard, cognized, and known. They conceal this conception, this forbearance, and this desire, and say:
I do not see, hear, cognize, or know.

Or regarding what is not seen, they have the conception of not having seen, and regarding what is not heard, cognized, or known, they have the conception of not having heard, cognized, or known. They conceal this conception, this forbearance, and this desire, and say:
I see, I hear, cognize, and know.
There is karma that is neither unwholesome nor inverted.ğŸ”½It is like
a person who gives rise to this view and establishes this thesis:
There is karma, there is the ripening of karma, and they still engage in good bodily, verbal, and mental actions.
Moreover,
it is like a person
If one has the perception of seeing, hearing, knowing, or perceiving, and the thought, tolerance, and desire to conceal this perception, and says:
I see, I hear, know, or perceive,
or if one has the perception of not seeing, not hearing, knowing, or perceiving, and the thought, tolerance, and desire to conceal this perception, and says:
I do not see, hear, know, or perceive,
if an action is wholesome, is that action non-erroneous?
Answer:
Four sentences should be made.
The second sentence above becomes the first sentence here.
The first sentence above becomes the second sentence here.ğŸ”½The fourth sentence above becomes the third sentence here.
The third sentence above becomes the fourth sentence here.
- as explained in detail above.
If one possesses unwholesome actions, does one possess actions bound to the form and formless realms?
Answer:
Those who possess unwholesome karma definitely possess karma bound to the form and formless realms.
There are those who possess karma bound to the form and formless realms but not unwholesome karma.
This refers to:
those born in the desire realm who have already separated from defilements of the desire realm;
or those born in the form realm.
If one possesses wholesome karma bound to the desire realm, does one possess karma bound to the form and formless realms?
Answer:
Those who possess wholesome karma bound to the desire realm definitely possess karma bound to the form and formless realms.
There are those who possess karma bound to the form and formless realms but not wholesome karma bound to the desire realm.
This refers to:
those who have severed wholesome roots, or those born in the form realm.
If one possesses wholesome karma bound to the desire realm, does one possess wholesome karma bound to the form and formless realms?
Answer:
One should make a fourfold distinction.
There are those who possess wholesome karma bound to the desire realm but not wholesome karma bound to the form and formless realms.
This refers to:ğŸ”½those born in the form and formless realms.
Born in the desire realm, not severing the roots of good, not yet attaining wholesome thoughts of the form realm.
There are those who accomplish wholesome actions bound to the form and formless realms, but not wholesome actions bound to the desire realm.
This refers to:
Those born in the form realm who attain wholesome thoughts of the formless realm.
There are those who accomplish wholesome actions bound to the desire realm, as well as wholesome actions bound to the form and formless realms.
This refers to:
Those born in the desire realm who attain wholesome thoughts of the formless realm.
There are those who do not accomplish wholesome actions bound to the desire realm, nor wholesome actions bound to the form and formless realms.
This refers to:
The person who has severed the roots of good.
If one accomplishes actions bound to the desire realm, do they accomplish actions bound to the form realm?
Answer:
It is so.
If one accomplishes actions bound to the form realm, do they accomplish actions bound to the desire realm?
Answer:
It is so.
If one accomplishes actions bound to the desire realm, do they accomplish actions bound to the formless realm?
Answer:
Those who have accomplished actions bound to the desire realm definitely have accomplished actions bound to the formless realm.
There are those who have accomplished actions bound to the formless realm but not actions bound to the desire realm.
Namely:
A person born in the formless realm.
If one has accomplished actions bound to the desire realm, have they accomplished unconditioned actions?
Answer:
One should make four statements.
There are those who have accomplished actions bound to the desire realm but not unconditioned actions.
Namely:
Ordinary beings born in the desire or form realms.
There are those who have accomplished unconditioned actions but not actions bound to the desire realm.
Namely:
Noble ones born in the formless realm.
There are those who have accomplished actions bound to the desire realm and also unconditioned actions.
Namely:
Noble ones born in the desire or form realms.
There are those who have not accomplished actions bound to the desire realm and also not unconditioned actions.
Namely:
Ordinary beings born in the formless realm.
If one has accomplished actions bound to the form realm, have they accomplished actions bound to the formless realm?
Answer:
Those who have perfected form-realm-bound karma definitely have perfected formless-realm-bound karma.
There are those who have perfected formless-realm-bound karma but not form-realm-bound karma.
Namely,
all sentient beings born in the formless realm.
If one has perfected form-realm-bound karma, does one have perfected unattached karma?
The answer is:
One should make four statements.
There are those who have perfected form-realm-bound karma but not unattached karma.
Namely,
ordinary beings born in the desire or form realms.
There are those who have perfected unattached karma but not form-realm-bound karma.
Namely,
noble ones born in the formless realm.
There are those who have perfected form-realm-bound karma and also unattached karma.
Namely,
noble ones born in the desire or form realms.
There are those who have neither perfected form-realm-bound karma nor unattached karma.
Namely,
ordinary beings born in the formless realm.
If one has perfected formless-realm-bound karma, does one have perfected unattached karma?
The answer is:
Those who have unconditioned karma definitely have karma bound to the formless realm.
There are those who have karma bound to the formless realm but not unconditioned karma.
Namely:
All ordinary beings.
If one has karma bound to the desire realm, form realm, formless realm, and unconditioned, where will they be reborn after death?
Answer:
Either in the desire realm, form realm, formless realm, or in a place of no rebirth.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
